title: Demand puts spotlight on aged care use
text:
However, CHSP is "bucket funding" and service providers can very quickly run out of money.

Once someone has been receiving services under CHSP for a fraction of the cost of what they may have to pay for a home care package, they can be, understandably, reluctant to change.

This is despite a home care package being potentially more robust.

The money within a home care package is yours to spend on appropriate care and equipment as you wish.

How packages work

There are four levels of home care packages to help meet older Australians' different levels of care need, determined by the outcome of an aged care assessment. The levels range from $8271 a year for a level one package to $50,286 a year for a level four.

You may be asked to pay fees when you take up a home care package. There is a basic daily fee, ranging from $9.52 a day to $10.63 a day depending on the package level. Remember these are charged daily even though you may only use a service once a fortnight. So $10 a day may not sound like much, but $140 a fortnight for a one-hour clean can be a lot if you're not using all the services to which you're entitled.

The basic daily fee is added to the government subsidy to enable additional care services to be provided. So for a level four package it is an additional $3879 a year to spend (less any case management and administration fees).

Advertisement

You may also be asked to pay an income-tested care fee.

If this is the case, the government subsidy to the home care provider is reduced by the income-tested care fee up to a capped amount.

We know from the government survey that not everyone is able to get the package level they are assessed for and may be allocated a lower package as an interim measure.

At the same time there are plenty of people who would rather pay less under CHSP or hold out for a higher level package than accept a lower level one and pay more.

This is where the "use it or lose it" comes in.

According to the Aged Care Assessment Team (ACAT), which makes the decision on the appropriate levels of government-subsidised support, the way to get a higher level package is to use what is available at a lower level first.

Funds going to waste

ACAT professionals are often asked to reassess someone for a higher package only to find that they are either sitting on surplus funds in a lower package or aren’t putting in place services.

Advertisement

Funds can accumulate for a number of reasons including during hospital stays and automatic package upgrades.

But more commonly it is the reluctance of some people to accept necessary additional care and support.

It is an understandable fear, yet it is one that may need to be overcome if someone wants to stay in their own home – and is getting the subsidised support to do so – rather than move into residential care.

In its latest Inside Aged Care study, insights agency Faster Horses found home care recipients frustrated either with the quantum of support available – they needed more hours of contact – or the scope of services provided.

Those looking ahead at the services they might need in five years were most likely to choose help around the house and garden, therapy services including podiatry and physio, followed by outings, personal assistance and social visits.

Faster Horses managing director Veronica Mayne says the data clearly shows that while medical assistance is required, mental wellbeing such as house and garden maintenance and socialising are also important.

She believes there is a need to balance the contractual and regulatory obligations of providers with a recognition that a need for a specific type of assistance may not always fall within an allocated home visit or fit neatly within a specific service category. Further, individuals need a balance of services ranging from physical and mental to social.

If you have a home care package, do your best to get the services it provides and the help you need. If you don’t use your package, then sooner or later someone else might.

Bina Brown is a director of aged care solutions company Third Age Matters.
description: It's unwise to 'hoard' funds from a home care package for a rainy day. If you don’t use them, sooner or later someone else might.
